awd_titl_txt: Case Studies of a Suite of Next Generation Science Instructional, Assessment and Professional Development Materials in Diverse Middle School Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
New state science standards are ambitious and require important changes to instructional practices, accompanied by a coordinated system of curriculum, assessment, and professional development materials. This project addresses a gap between vision and implementation of such standards by designing a coordinated suite of instructional, assessment and teacher professional learning materials that attempt to enact the vision behind the Next Generation Science Standards. The study focuses on the design of such materials using state-of-the-art technology to create an 8-week long, immersive, life science field experience organized around three investigations. Classes of urban students in two states will collect data on local insect species with the goal of understanding, sharing, and critiquing environmental management solutions. An integrated learning technology system, the Learning Navigator, draws on big data to organize student-gathered data, dialogue, lessons, an assessment information. The Learning Navigator will also amplify the teacher's role in guiding and fostering next generation science learning. This project advances the field through an in-depth exploration of the goals for the standards documents. The study begins to address questions about what works when, where, and for whom in the context of the Next Generation Science Standards. 

The project uses a series of case studies to create, test, evaluate and refine the system of instructional, assessment and professional development materials as they are enacted in two distinct urban school settings. It is designed with 330 students and 22 teachers in culturally, racially and linguistically diverse, under-resourced schools in Pennsylvania and California. These schools are located in neighborhoods that are economically challenged and have students who demonstrate patterns of underperformance on state standardized tests. It will document the process of team co-construction of Next Generation Science-fostering instructional materials; develop assessment tasks for an instructional unit that are valid and reliable; and, track the patterns of use of the instructional and assessment materials by teachers. The study will also record if new misconceptions are revealed as students develop Next Generation Science knowledge,  comparing findings across two diverse school locations in two states. Data collection will include: (a) multiple types of data to establish validity and reliability of educational assessments, (b) the design, evaluation and use of a classroom observation protocol to gather information on both frequency and categorical degree of classroom practices that support the vision, and (c) consecutive years of ten individual classroom enactments through case studies analyzed through cross-case analyses. This should lead to stronger and better developed understandings about what constitutes strong Next Generation Science learning and the classroom conditions, instructional materials, assessments and teacher development -- that foster it.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes

The global pandemic and climate change have created serious environmental, social, and economic challenges. Interdisciplinary STEM education that provides learning opportunities for students to ask, analyze, and develop solutions to local problems is more important than ever, yet few pre-college programs prepare students to apply scientific investigations to the design of engineered solutions.

Intellectual Merit

This project developed, evaluated, and refined instructional programs and tools to guide and support students in designing solutions to address local environmental problems. The resources developed included: 

  • Three six-week curriculum programs for students in grades 4-9.
  • Two technology tools:
    • Gooru Learning Navigator – an interactive system organizing curriculum, assessments, and teaching materials.
    • Animal Diversity Web Pocket Guide – a web tool helping students identify local insects and find solutions to environmental issues, and
  • Mixed methods research studies focused on the co-construction of instructional materials, student learning in science and engineering, student interest and motivation in conjunction with engineering design of solutions to local environmental issues, and the development of a new Iterative Science and Engineering Instructional Model. One set of research studies used a Design-Based Research (DBR) approach over three cycles, showing significant improvements in students' learning. 

Key outcomes include:

  1. Student Learning Gains – Improvements in science and engineering understanding, particularly in Cycle 3. This improvement was realized as a result of multiple iterations of dimensions of science investigation (Explore, Explain) followed by engineering design and sharing/critique (Engineer, Educate; see Figures 1 and 2).
  2. Effective Instructional Model – The Iterative Science and Engineering (ISE) instructional model was developed, refined and tested, integrating science investigation with engineering design and resulting in student-created solutions.
  3. Curriculum Development – Three versions of the ISE-aligned curriculum were created for elementary, middle, and high school students in urban and rural settings.
  4. Student Engagement – Data showed a strong, complex relationship between student interest in STEM and their learning progress.

Broader Impacts

The project directly involved 1,108 students and 11 teachers in under-resourced schools in Philadelphia and Utah. The project provided resources and interdisciplinary, three-dimensional STEM learning opportunities, strengthened partnerships with educators, and ensured that the instructional resources would continue to benefit students beyond the funding period. Publications and Dissemination – The project resulted in 12 research papers, two tech tools, three e-books, 20 presentations, and two book chapters. The findings and materials continue to be shared with schools, policymakers, and the broader STEM education community.
